page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: King John is said to have visited Dundonald in 1210, then indicating its importance in royal eyes. The fortress was destroyed in the fourteenth century when Edward Bruce invaded Ulster. The modern history of Dundonald dates from the Anglo - Scots plantation of Ulster in the seventeenth century. A Scot called James Hamilton acquired Dundonald by dubious means and a village grew up round the "green". In the great rebellion of 1641 fortifications were erected to prevent an invasion of the Ards Peninsula by the rebels. in 1688 The Duke of Schomberg passed through Dundonald on his way to Belfast damaging the road with his heavy artillery pieces.
